bestBHT.bht: Our fight against sin requires courage and perseverance, like an athlete who experiences bruises. Just as an athlete cannot bring great courage to the contest without being bruised, we must face sin head-on and not let our spirits be cast down. It is through our resistance to sin that we grow stronger and more determined. While our struggle may not entail the shedding of our blood, it is important to recognize that our trials and sufferings are part of the process of subduing sin and increasing holiness.

Henry Alford: An athlete cannot bring great courage to the contest who has never been bruised.

He who has seen his own blood, whose teeth have crashed beneath the fist, he who has been thrown and borne the weight of his adversary on him, and has not been prostrated in his spirit, who as often as he has fallen has risen more indomitable in spirit, he it is who comes down to the fight with great hope.
The resisting that sin of unfaithfulness which would lead them to spare their blood, would, if carried far enough, lead to the shedding of it.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The athlete who hath seen his own blood, and who, though cast down by his opponent, does not let his spirits be cast down, who as often as he hath fallen hath risen the more determined, goes down to the encounter with great hope" [SENECA].

Sin is personified as an adversary; sin, whether within you, leading you to spare your blood, or in our adversaries, leading them to shed it, if they cannot through your faithfulness even unto blood, induce you to apostatize.
Albert Barnes: Great as your trials may seem to have been, yet your faith has not yet been put to the severest test. And since this is so, you ought not to yield in the conflict with evil, but manfully resist it.

The expression 'striving against sin' seems to demand... the struggle of the Redeemer in the garden with the great enemy who there made his most violent assault, and where the resistance of the Redeemer was so great as to force the blood through his pores.
If we could keep him [the Redeemer] in the eye resisting even unto blood rather than yield in the least degree, it would do more than all other things to restrain us from sin.
Marvin Vincent: Your strife against sin has not entailed the shedding of your blood, as did that of many of the O. T. worthies, and of Jesus himself."
Of Jesus it is said, Philippians 2:8, 'he became obedient to the extent of death [μεχρι θανατου].' Comp. 2 Macc. 13 14.
John Calvin: He only teaches us, that the persecutions which we endure for the Gospel’s sake, are on another account useful to us, even because they are remedies to destroy sin.
Thus God’s grace towards us is twofold — the remedies he applies to heal our vices, he employs for the purpose of defending his gospel.
There is therefore no reason for us to ask a discharge from the Lord, whatever service we may have performed; for Christ will have no discharged soldiers, but those who have conquered death itself.
Philip Schaff: Special care is still needed, for there may be severer trials in store.
How poor our modern self-denial is, compared with what the first Christians suffered.
Happier times call for the greater voluntary consecration.
Archibald T. Robertson: Resisted (αντικατεστητε). Second aorist active indicative (intransitive) of the double compound αντικαθιστημ, old verb to stand in opposition against in line of battle, intransitively to stand face to face (αντ) against (κατα), here only in the N.T.
Unto blood (μεχρις αιματος). 'Up to blood.' As was true of Jesus and many of the other heroes of faith in chapter Hebrews 12:11.
Striving (ανταγωνιζομενο). Present middle participle of ανταγωνιζομα, old verb with the same figure in αντικατεστητε. Against sin (προς αμαρτιαν). Face to face with sin as in verse Hebrews 12:1.
John Gill: They had resisted sin, and Satan, and the world, the men of it, and the lusts of it, and its frowns and flatteries, and also false teachers, even every adversary of Christ, and their souls.
They must expect to suffer as long as they were in the world, and had blood in them; and that their blood, when called for, should be spilled for the sake of Christ.

Now this is said, to sharpen and increase the saints resentment and indignation against it, as being their antagonist, with whom they strive and combat, and which is the cause of all the evils in the world, exposes to wrath to come, and separates from communion with God; and to encourage them to bear their sufferings patiently, since they are not without sin, as Christ was; and since their afflictions and sufferings are for the subduing of sin, and the increase of holiness.
John Wesley: Unto blood — Unto wounds and death.

bhtAttempts.bht: We are reminded that the struggle against sin requires great courage and determination, just as an athlete cannot compete without enduring bruises. Our fight against sin is not just an internal battle, but often involves resisting external forces as well. The heroics of Jesus and the faithful heroes of the Old Testament exemplify this, as they shed their blood in their faithfulness to God. Our own wrestling with sin may not have entailed such sacrifice, but it is still a significant endeavor. We must resist sin face to face, knowing that our suffering and trials serve as remedies to destroy sin and defend the gospel. We should not shy away from these struggles, even if they call for the spilling of our own blood. Let us be strengthened and encouraged in our fight against sin, knowing that our endurance brings greater holiness and victory over the enemy.

An athlete's bravery is tested through bruises, just as our faithfulness is tested through resistance against sin. It is crucial to acknowledge that our struggle against sin is not limited to internal battles; it often involves resisting external forces as well. The heroes of faith in the Bible shed their blood in their unwavering commitment to God, inspiring us to face our own trials with great hope. As we face these struggles head-on, knowing that they are remedies to destroy sin, we are encouraged to endure, for it is through our suffering that we grow stronger and more faithful.

Our fight against sin requires courage and perseverance, like an athlete who experiences bruises. Just as an athlete cannot bring great courage to the contest without being bruised, we must face sin head-on and not let our spirits be cast down. It is through our resistance to sin that we grow stronger and more determined. While our struggle may not entail the shedding of our blood, it is important to recognize that our trials and sufferings are part of the process of subduing sin and increasing holiness.

In our fight against sin, we must summon courage and resilience, much like athletes who endure bruises. We cannot shy away from our struggle, for it encompasses both internal and external resistance. The faithful heroes of the past shed blood in their unwavering commitment to God and His ways. Although our trials may not compare, we must remember that our suffering serves as a remedy to destroy sin and defend the gospel. As we face tribulations, let us endure with hope and perseverance, for they lead to greater holiness.

The fight against sin requires courage and resilience, much like an athlete who perseveres despite being bruised. We must not be disheartened by our struggles, but instead rise stronger every time we fall. While our resistance may not entail shedding blood, it is through these trials that we grow closer to God and deepen our faith. Our endurance in the face of sin serves as a remedy to overcome its power and defend the gospel. Let us embrace our sufferings, knowing that they contribute to our sanctification and the victory over sin.
